In Kierkegaard's philosophy, the knight of infinite resignation and the knight of faith are two different stages of existence.

The knight of infinite resignation is a person who accepts the limitations of the finite world and relinquishes all earthly desires and ambitions. This person recognizes that all worldly goals are ultimately futile, and accepts their inability to achieve them. They may still feel sadness or regret for what they cannot attain, but they accept it as part of the finite human condition.

On the other hand, the knight of faith is a person who takes a leap of faith into the infinite. They do not simply accept the limitations of the finite world, but instead trust in something beyond it. This leap of faith is not based on reason or evidence, but on an intuition or feeling that there is something more. The knight of faith may still engage with the finite world, but their ultimate allegiance is to the infinite.

Kierkegaard's example of the knight of faith is Abraham, who was willing to sacrifice his son Isaac in obedience to God's command. Abraham did not know why God was asking him to do this, but he had faith that it was the right thing to do.
